Gamespot Staff
Poe to Star in Apocalypse?
Fingers are pointing to rocker Poe as possible "co-star" in Activision's upcoming release.
Gamespot Staff
Peep Show: Sega's New Console Creeps Out of the Shadows
The elusive Black Belt, Sega's fourth-generation console, is quietly being built here in the US, though we may never see the fruits of Sega's labor. Our four-part story on Sega's hidden agenda begins today.
Gamespot Staff
Namco Set to Rage
Prime the shrink-wrap, Rage Racer is ready to roll.
Chris Johnston
Sub-Zero Game Taking Shape
Midway's Mortal Kombat prequel looms. Here are a few screenshots to help you wait out its release.
Jeff Gerstmann
Wanderlust's Road Gets Bumpy
The company reportedly cuts staff by 50 percent, focuses on Adrenalin-developed titles.
Gamespot Staff
Working Designs Goes Retro
Saturn gamers have something to celebrate, as Working Designs' new Spaz label brings Sega arcade hits home.
Chris Johnston
Your Logo Here
It's a fact of life in the movies, but is product placement inevitable on the small screen, too?
James Glave
Street Racer Released for PC
The 3-D racer, already out for PlayStation, is described as "a cross between Super Mario Kart and Street Fighter." UbiSoft's Street Racer features 27 tracks (three are hidden), four difficulty levels and eight cartoonish opponents with special weapons - and comes bundled with Rayman.
Helen Lee
Interactive Magic Merges with Interactive Creations
The ink has dried on the deal first announced last January. The companies will team up to create a new online gaming venue.
Helen Lee
3D WinBench 97: What Is it Good for?
The people who brought you Winstone and WinBench have released a new benchmark test that objectively measures your system's 3-D graphic performance. Find out how to get the ZDBOp-designed program.
Vince Broady
IDSA President Says Future Looks Good
Quality software and a renewed concentration on development studios, affiliated label programs continue to drive the gaming industry to new highs.
Chris Johnston
Sky Target Takes Aim in Japan
Here's our first look at Sega's just-released Saturn shooter.
Jeff Gerstmann
For Spectrum HoloByte, Less Is More
Quarterly net profit is attributed to lineup of fewer - but better - games. Strong sales of Civilization II didn't hurt either.
Helen Lee
IDSA Sees Boom Times Ahead
A surge in first quarter software sales for computers and video game consoles appears to signal good times for the interactive entertainment industry.
Chris Johnston
Nintendo of Australia Lowers N64 Price
And throws in a free game as well. Who do they think they are…Sega?
Chris Johnston
Virtual British Open Begins Next Week
Winner of the Virtual British Open will win a trip to the real thing in Scotland.
Helen Lee
Electronic Arts Breaks Out the Bubbly
As a result of a profitable year, stock brokers say go for it.
Helen Lee
Softimage Looks to PlayStation
Sony gets the kind of 3-D graphics and rendering tools that will give developers more freedom to create killer PlayStation applications.
Chris Johnston
Sir, There's a Flaw in My Chip
Tomorrow, Intel releases its Pentium II chip for PC and coin-op use, although reports of a flaw have surfaced.
Chris Johnston
GT Interactive Reports First Quarter Results
The company made US$93 million in revenues, but net income remained almost the same.
Chris Johnston
And Now for the Numbers
NPD Group reports that millions and millions of game software titles were bought in the quarter ending March 31. Curious to know how many?
Chris Johnston
MDK Arrives
Playmates Interactive's action-strategy title MDK ships today to retailers nationwide. The American version (the game is already out in the UK) comes with a save feature the Euro release sorely lacks. A PlayStation version of the title is scheduled for release in July.
Gamespot Staff
Psygnosis' Sentient Hits the PC
Psygnosis has shipped a PC version of Sentient, a real-time science fiction adventure already available on PlayStation. The game is reminiscent of early text-driven adventures, in which gamers explore different, randomly generated plots in 200 locations in and around a space station.
Helen Lee
The HEAT Is On
The wait is finally over for those wanting a taste of SegaSoft's entry into online gaming.
Rebecca Anderson
TEN Launches Version 1.2
The online gaming service lowers prices, implements new features, to make friends and keep them connected.
Rebecca Anderson
It's Playtime in Latin America
MDK, Chessmaster 5000, MAX and four other games are due there by the end of the year.
Helen Lee
Bandai Names President
Turbulent week at toymaker sees president and six company directors leave their posts.
Gamespot Staff
Enter the Gecko
For the sequel to Gex, everyone's favorite gecko hero goes up against a resurrected Rez.
Chris Johnston
Sega to Build Future on Software, Not Hardware
Since the failed merger, Sega's forecast for the next year includes a focus on quality games.
Chris Johnston
Ubi Soft Announces Atlanta Lineup
Tonic Trouble, Formula 1 racing and soccer games are coming from the creator of POD and Rayman.
Helen Lee
Ripcord Grows
Adding to its list of games, Panasonic Interactive Media will publish space combat title Forced Alliance under its new game label, Ripcord. Earlier this week, the company announced it would publish Running With Scissors' Postal.
Gamespot Staff
Bandai President To Step Down
Accepting responsibility for the breakdown of merger talks between Bandai and Sega, Makato Yamashina to resign.
Gamespot Staff
Sega, Bandai Merger Canceled
Two of the biggest toy and electronic game makers in the world decide to work together instead of merge.
Chris Johnston
First Look: Tomb Raider 2
Lara Croft's second adventure looks even better than the first.

War games show the Army's new computer system - designed to make war more efficient - vulnerable to a variety of battlefield conditions.

Activision will be publishing Hipnotic Interactive's SiN, a first-person action game that uses the Quake engine.

Helen Lee
Skyline Announces New Arcade Locations
Skyline Multimedia Entertainment to expand franchise to Chicago and Sydney, Australia.
Kate Hedstrom
Bethesda's E3 Lineup
The 10th Planet and The Elder Scrolls Adventures: Redguard will make appearances at June's trade show.
Helen Lee
Sega and Bandai Fix Date
Yesterday, Bandai Co. Ltd. announced that it will sign a merger agreement with Sega Enterprises Ltd. on May 28. The merger, announced last January, will be completed October 1. The two companies will then be known as SegaBandai. Additionally, earnings reports for both companies have been postponed until May 28th.
Chris Johnston
Star Trek Generations Ships
Spectrum HoloByte's Star Trek Generations, an action-adventure game, has shipped and will soon be in stores. Along with the release, the company is sponsoring promotions with MSN, Pepsi, and Paramount...including a trivia-based scavenger hunt starting June 1.
Helen Lee
Lion Takes Life of Gamer
Tragic story of four-year old boy mauled while playing video games in Brazil.
Chris Johnston
MAK and TEN Team Up
MAK Technologies, developers of software for military simulations, will create an online-only space combat game for TEN.
Helen Lee
DID Joins Debate Over F-22
Whose F-22 is it anyway? Digital Image Design invites Lockheed Martin, NovaLogic, and Interactive Magic for a chat.
Helen Lee

Demo version has us glued to the console.

Six games will be previewed, including Chasm - The Shadow Zone and Outlaw Racers.

Interplay's sports arm will publish Jimmy Johnson's VR Football '98 for the PlayStation this summer.

GS News has obtained exclusive screenshots and video footage of DreamWorks' upcoming Playstation and Saturn title.

Twilight Lands and Confirmed Kill are among the titles expected on the gaming service.

EA Ships Triple Play 98
Electronic Arts' baseball title for PlayStation boasts two-man play-by-play, enhanced AI, baseball trivia, and crowd intelligence (in which crowd size and energy level depend on how well a team is doing) ships today. The title should be in stores in a few days.
Helen Lee

Chris Johnston
Deep Blue Sinks Kasparov
In a six-game rematch, Kasparov loses to IBM's chess-playing supercomputer.
Helen Lee
Mad Genius To Show GunMetal
Scheduled for release this summer, GunMetal is a 25-level science fiction PC title in a world 300 years in the future.
Helen Lee
Same Castle, Different Ghost
Slay monsters, take potions, confront wretched monsters, and combat evil elements in a medieval world. Ecstatica II, the sequel to 1995's Ecstatica, has shipped; from Psygnosis.

The mother of all commercial online services is said to be on the cusp of charging a fee for online gaming.

Helen Lee
Nintendo Lineup in Action
Here's a peek at what Nintendo will be showcasing at the E3 show in Atlanta next week.
High Expectations for Sony
Sony said on Thursday that it expects total global shipments of its PlayStation console to reach 31.5 million units by the end of March 1998. "We plan to produce 18 million machines in the 1997-98 business year," a spokesperson said.
Gamespot Staff
Interplay Readies Clayfighter 63 1/3
Interplay's Clayfighter 63 1/3 prepares to make some dough on the N64.
Chris Johnston
PlayStations On the Rise
Sony reported Wednesday that worldwide shipments of PlayStation consoles reached 16 million units as of the end of May. Current production of the unit stands at 1.5 million a month. In addition, by Sony's measure 114 million PlayStation games have shipped worldwide.
Gamespot Staff
Matsushita Plays Peekaboo
M2 Maker Says Machine Is Ready; Others Beg to Differ.
Curt Feldman
Playmates Readies E3 Product Slate
Hard-core console and PC titles fill Playmates' E3 lineup.
Chris Johnston
Lords of the Realm II Enhanced
Lords of the Realm II Siege Pack, an add-on to the 1996 PC strategy game, is out. The new product from Sierra On-Line features a skirmish-only mode (so players can jump straight into battle), new battle locations, a new map editor, and head-to-head Internet combat.
Helen Lee
Age of Empires Shows Off its Wonders
Microsoft Games provides a first look at its long-awaited historical real-time strategy game.
Tim Soete
EA Scores a Triple Play
Electronic Arts has released Triple Play 98 for the PC. The baseball game has a new 3-D game engine, enhanced AI, and two-man play-by-play and color commentary from Jim Hughson and Buck Martinez. The PC version has modem and LAN play for up to four players.
Helen Lee
Sony Becomes Official NBA Sponsor
As the NBA Finals rage on, Sony makes a deal with the NBA to become an official sponsor.
Chris Johnston
MGM's E3 Lineup
PC and PlayStation action titles dominate MGM Interactive's list of games to be shown at E3.
Chris Johnston
EA/Bullfrog Brings Populous to PlayStation
Once thought to be a PC-only title, the third game in the Populous series will be ported to the PlayStation, GS News learned Friday. Populous: The Third Coming is expected to hit retail shelves at the end of the year.
Chris Johnston
Demos to Get Your Blood Pumping
New action demos by Activision and MGM Interactive feature heroes who deal a little more than a scrape on the elbow to their villains.
Tim Soete
Rebel Moon Setting
GT Interactive officials informed GS News this morning that it has officially canceled the PlayStation version of the first-person shooter Rebel Moon Rising. It's likely the decision was reached because of the poor reception the PC version (which was MMX only) garnered.
Joe Fielder
Nintendo Dreams of Banjo & Kazooie
New information reveals the names of the two stars of Rare's top secret Nintendo 64 project.
Chris Johnston
Mindscape Does Good
Mindscape Sports Advantage will host Jackie Robinson Day in San Francisco this weekend.
Helen Lee
Jack Nicklaus Improves Game
Accolade releases an upgrade patch for Jack Nicklaus 4.
Tasos Kaiafas
X-Men on My PC?
Acclaim releases a demo of X-Men fighting game; the full version to be part of a bargain package.
Tim Soete
Sega Lowers Saturn Price to $149
Saturn now shares the same price as Sony and Nintendo systems; analysts wonder is it enough?
Chris Johnston
Duke Nukem Sitting Pretty
GT Interactive's macho mascot will make an appearance as a porcelain figurine. Whatever you do, don't call it a doll.
Gamespot Staff
TH*Q Gets 'Lost' on Game Boy
TH*Q nabs the Lost World license for a new Game Boy title this fall.
Chris Johnston
Fore Play
PGA Tour Pro from Electronic Arts ships today. Besides the game's licensed courses that include Pebble Beach and Spyglass Hill, the title is ready for play over the Internet through EA Sports Net. Up to 80 players can compete in a single online tournament.
Gamespot Staff
E-Pub Picks Up Speed
The company behind online gaming site CosmOasis is hoping to have a big summer.
Gamespot Staff
Bulls 'Victorious'
Using NBA Shoot Out '97, Sony has predicted the winner of the NBA Playoffs - the Chicago Bulls. In Sony's version of the NBA Playoffs, the Bulls dominated the series, with the Utah Jazz winning only one game of five. Satellite TV owners can watch the mock games this weekend via a special broadcast.
Chris Johnston
He's Back
They said it couldn't happen. They were wrong. Earthworm Jim is, once again, ready for his close-up.
Joe Fielder
GameSpot's Game Forecast
Find out what PC CD-ROM titles are due out in the coming months.
Gamespot Staff
TH*Q Brings Out Two New Titles
Bravo Air Race for the PlayStation, and WCW Vs. NWO: World Tour for Nintendo 64 heat up TH*Q's lineup.
Chris Johnston
Activision Gets Quake II
id and Activision make a major deal to publish the anticipated sequel to Quake.
Helen Lee
Simutronics Gamer Convention
Simutronics Corporation's Multiplayer Online Game Players' Convention is taking place in St. Louis his weekend. The event will focus on the company's text-based games, GemStone III , DragonRealms, and Modus Operandi. Game developers will be in attendance. The company's web site has additional information.
Gamespot Staff
A Crash Course in Runabout
Climax Entertainment has released Yaroman Games' Runabout to crash-happy gamers in Japan.
Jeff Gerstmann
SegaSoft Preps for E3
The company will showcase Heat.net, along with a few original titles that will be available both on CD-ROM and Heat.
Helen Lee
Resident Evil: Director's Cut Due From Capcom
New areas and a special bonus demo come for PlayStation this fall.
Chris Johnston
Sega Ventures Into 'Lost' Territory
The new Model 3-based Jurassic Park arcade game looks to be one of Sega's hot arcade properties for 1997.
Chris Johnston
T*HQ Gets New Board Member
James Whims, who once headed the North American launch of the PlayStation, is now on T*HQ's team.
Helen Lee
Tamagotchi vs. Giga Pets: Virtual Battle Royale
Virtual Pets from Bandai and Tiger vie for kids' attention, care, and pocket money; the hype can be heard 'round the world.
Chris Johnston
PC Data Releases Monthly Numbers
Diablo, Microsoft Flight Sim, and Command &Conquer Red Alert retain top three spots; Magic: The Gathering makes first chart appearance.
Helen Lee
Shadows of the Empire Coming to PCs Everywhere
LucasArts has announced the fall release of a PC version of Shadows of the Empire. The game, the part of the saga that takes place between The Empire Strikes Back and Return of the Jedi, features five types of gameplay, ten huge levels, over four storyline twists, new characters, vehicles, and locations - along with the sound effects and music of the Star Wars universe. The title was originally released for Nintendo 64 late last year.
Helen Lee
Hexen Casts Its Spell
GT Interactive confirmed the release date of the PlayStation version of Hexen to GS News. PlayStation gamers will be able to play the game on their system beginning May 16, while N64 owners will have to wait until June. The game is a conversion of the hit PC title originally done by 3D Realms and id Software. Hexen combines a Doom-style interface with magic spells and abilities.
Gamespot Staff
Mindscape Brings Creatures to the US
This virtual pet for the PC is described by Mindscape as similar to gerbils - which has us wondering.
Helen Lee
Duke Lives Out Penthouse Fantasy
GT Interactive and Intersphere have created a new level for Duke Nukem 3D; Penthouse Pets poised to star
Helen Lee
Acclaim Reduces Staff by 115
Acclaim Entertainment, publishers of the recently-released Turok: Dinosaur Hunter, announced today that it was eliminating 115 positions. The company also plans to consolidate administrative and operational functions, and reduce operating budgets in a restructuring move they hope will result in savings of about $40 million. In April, Acclaim reported a second-quarter loss of $16.8 million, compared with a $55.8 million loss for the same quarter in 1996.
Gamespot Staff
Sega Gives Blockbuster the Mix Early
Sega announced yesterday that it would be shipping its newest title, Fighters Megamix, to Blockbuster stores eleven days before its release at retail outlets nationwide. The game brings together all the fighters from Sega's Virtua Fighter 2 and Fighting Vipers, plus ten hidden warriors. Megamix will be available for rent at Blockbuster beginning May 2. The game's retail release isn't until the 13th.
Gamespot Staff
Star Fox Gets Retitled for Europe
The 64-bit sequel to Star Fox will get a name revision for its release into the European market this fall.
Chris Johnston
Sega Announces 'Big Title Collection'
Compile and Capcom join Sega in announcing its upcoming games at a summer press conference.
Chris Johnston
The Return of Zero Divide
Zoom's sequel to the early PlayStation robot fighter Zero Divide shipped in Japan late last week; they call it Zero Divide 2: The Secret Wish.
Joe Fielder
Virgin Does Disney
Disney's Hercules, which hit movie theaters on June 27, is also Virgin Interactive's latest PlayStation game.
Jeff Gerstmann
Megamedia Launches Two
Megamedia has launched two Web sites to promote its Outlaw Racers and Submarine Titans games. Outlaw Racers is a road rally game scheduled for release this fall, and Submarine Titans is an action game scheduled for release in early 1998. Both games are optimized for 3-D acceleration.
Gamespot Staff
Heat Gets Secure
SegaSoft licenses Open Market technology for Heat.
Helen Lee
War Games
EA and AT&T are sponsoring a tour of military bases and airshows to show off games to military personnel.
Helen Lee
Seta Brings Nintendo 64 to Arcades
Via new arcade architecture based on the Nintendo 64 hardware, Seta brings N64 action to the coin-op world.
Chris Johnston
Free Online Play at Microsoft
Online classic card games to remain free on the Zone.
Helen Lee
SNK Still 'King of Fighters'
SNK's latest King of Fighters installment has a few new options and characters awaiting players.
Chris Johnston
Star Trek: The Experience is Delayed
Las Vegas must wait for Star Trek theme attraction.
Helen Lee
TH*Q Announces Yearly Results
At the company's annual meeting, TH*Q announces its results, looks to the future.
Chris Johnston
Car and Driver Endorses Grand Tour Racing '98
Activision's PlayStation racer gets endorsement from the world's most read automotive magazine.
Chris Johnston
Sega Storms Tokyo
Sega introduces two new Model 3 arcade games at a private showing in Tokyo.
Chris Johnston
Micro Machines Crosses the Ocean
According to Sony's PlayStation web site, GT Interactive will be releasing Codemasters' European PlayStation title, Micro Machines V3. The game topped UK game charts in March, becoming number one just two days after its release. The game features eight-player simultaneous racing, mutliple tracks and environments, and a variety of vehicles to choose from. GS News contacted GT today; the company declined to comment on its release plans.
Gamespot Staff
Wave's Bright Idea
Video game rentals have bolstered the profits in that industry; Wave Systems wants to see if that model will work for PC games.
Helen Lee
Exclusive Prey Screenshots
The latest screenshots for 3D Realms' upcoming action title Prey.
Tim Soete
Tekken 3: The Arrival
Namco's third title in the Tekken series will appear for Japan and US gamers simultaneously.
Chris Johnston
3DO Says Goodbye Hardware
3DO finally gets rid of the machine that started 32-bit gaming.
Chris Johnston
Sony's Name Game
Sony's San Francisco-based entertainment center is now officially called Metreon.
Chris Johnston
MTV and GT Interactive Pair Up
GT Interactive and MTV have signed a multititle publishing agreement which will see the release of titles including Beavis and Butt-head and Aeon Flux.
Helen Lee
Nintendo To Rerelease N64 Favorites
In Japan, Nintendo Co. Ltd. rereleases Wave Race and Super Mario 64 - both with some improvements.
Chris Johnston
Whoa Montezuma!
Utopia Technologies is said to be close to inking a deal with a publisher who will handle the PlayStation and N64 versions of their impressive looking Montezuma's Return, its PC title shown last week at E3.
Joe Fielder
GT Goes on a Binge
ln a suprise move, GT Interactive, publisher for Duke Nukem 3D, announced today that it had acquired SingleTrac Entertainment. SingleTrac is best known for popular PlayStation titles such as: WarHawk, Twisted Metal, and Jet Moto. Once more information is known, check back with E3 News to get the entire story.
Micheal Mullen
Hasbro Interactive Announces H.E.D.Z.
Hasbro Interactive's H.E.D.Z. (Head Extreme Destruction Zone) PC title will also be coming out for the PlayStation.
Joe Fielder
DVD or Bust
The first made-for-DVD title from the genX Software and dHouse alliance will be shown this week at E3. Dead Moon Junction is the first of three titles the companies are working on. Dead Moon will get a retail release later this year, while the other two still-untitled games are slated to be released in 1998.

In an effort to "streamline existing operations and refocus its resources on mission critical objectives," TEN lays off fifteen.

Palladium Interactive, developers of Pyst, yesterday closed a round of financing led by Scripps Ventures.

Nintendo Takes Low Road On Pricing
Word on the web has it that N64 gamers may see cheaper prices for their favorite games very soon. Facing competition in software pricing from both Sega and Sony, Nintendo will supposedly announce a lowering in the MSRP of all new Nintendo 64 software. Nintendo could not confirm the reports.

Acclaim, leaner and meaner (thanks to recent layoffs and the success of Turok), has confirmed that Turok 2 for the N64 is in development. Acclaim is not divulging any details at this point, but sources within the company acknowledge a release before March 1998 is unlikely.

Also, OB's original designers are now at work on SquareSoft's Final Fantasy Tactics for the PlayStation.

Chris Johnston
USPS Sends a Message
The US Postal Service expresses its disapproval of the moniker for Running With Scissor's new game, Postal.
Helen Lee
Konami Expects Profits
Konami anticipates that strong sales of their video game software should result in a projected profit of 9 billion yen in this fiscal year. The company has not performed as well since 1989, when they posted a record profit of 8.9 billion yen. Konami expects software sales for both home consoles and arcade markets to grow significantly this year due to recent advancements in 3D graphics technology.

Multitude Passes Go; Collects US$1.6 Million

This opens the door for the start-up to reveal its new online multiplayer game, FireTeam. Multitude has created a new game genre for FireTeam, called collaborative play. The title will be shown at E3.

ENGAGE Goes to Europe
ENGAGE games online signed a multiyear distribution agreement with Internet service provider ICL. European gamers can now play on the service with gamers in the US and Asia. ENGAGE will form part of a Western European online games and entertainment venue on ICL called GamesZone. Users on ICL will pay on a per-minute basis.

Acclaim's Turok: Dinosaur Hunter has worked its way to the top spot among N64 titles sold in Japan, Acclaim said today. The company says total retails sales of the title worldwide exceed $60 million. The title was released in Japan on May 30.

Chris Johnston
Albert Odyssey Almost Complete
Working Designs expects Sega to give WD's title, Albert Odyssey, final approval tonight. Master discs on the title would then go to final production tomorrow. If this scenario holds, expect the title on retailer's shelves on the 15th or 16th of July.
Gamespot Staff
Studio e, Inland, THQ Fight Finished
Studio e, Inland Productions and THQ have agreed to disagree no more. All lawsuits and countersuits the parties had flowing through the legal system have been withdrawn. Studio e had charged that its production facilities had been inappropriately used by two Inland software developers collaborating on a THQ sports title.

Scavenger Sues GT
Details were slim at press time, but individuals representing game developer Scavenger say a complaint was filed Friday in New York Supreme Court (that state's lowest court) against GT Interactive alleging breach of contract. Scavenger is seeking in excess of US$100 million from GT.

Chris Johnston
Acrophobia Coming
Berkeley Systems will launch the Internet word game Acrophobia on its BeZerk.com Web site in October. In Acrophobia, gamers are presented 3 to 7 letters and given 60 seconds to create a "funny or witty" acronym that the letters could represent.

M3 Group To Distribute CyberCoin Payment System
CyberCash annouced today that it has retained M3 Group to distribute the CyberCoin online microtransaction service to PC and online game publishers and developers. CyberCoin allows publishers to provide customers with the ability to make secure Internet payments as low as US$.25 through a credit card or bank account.

Conquest Earth Ships
Eidos Interactive today announced that it was shipping Conquest Earth. In the real-time action/strategy game, players can assume the role of gaseous morphing aliens or humans, and can attempt to either destroy or defend humanity. The game sports single-player and multiplayer options, for up to eight players at a time.

And a PlayStation Shall Lead Them
Hanging its hat on high sales of its PlayStation console unit, Sony Corp. of Japan said net profits increased by 62 percent in the quarter ending September 1997. The company said group net profit totaled 56 billion yen (US$467 million) on sales of 1.63 trillion yen ($13.6 billion), up 20 percent from a year earlier.

Joe Fielder
FireTeam Start-up Fees
GameSpot incorrectly identified the start-up fees for the FireTeam online game as US$90. In fact, the fees are $50 and include the headset, CD, player manual, and $40 worth of game-play tokens.
Gamespot Staff
Bandai Founder Dies
Naoharu Yamashina, who founded the Bandai Company in 1950, died last Tuesday in Japan. He was 79 and died after an illness that had kept him hospitalized since June. Yamashina started selling toys in Tokyo in 1947. The then-named Bandaiya Company's first product was a beach ball with a bell inside. Currently, the company is riding the phenomenal wave of sales (and revenues) of its Tamagotchi key chain, which has sold 21 million units worldwide.

Counterfeiters Beware
Hoping to put an end to the pirating of PlayStation discs, Sony filed lawsuits against six individuals Sony claims have sold illegally copied software over the Internet. The suits, filed Tuesday, charge the six (John Liadis, Ch Shum, Leon Ho, Robert Lu, C. Chiang, and Arnold Burian) with copyright and trademark infringement.

Capcom has shipped the long-awaited Super Street Fighter II Collection, a three-in-one compilation of three of the games in Capcom's popular Street Fighter II series. Harley Jebens
NetLink Talks
If all goes according to Sega of Japan's plans, Saturn owners who choose can use their NetLink modem and Sega Saturn console units to send and retrieve voice mail messages. Sega hopes the voice mail option will stimulate sales of the modem unit that has underperformed, sales-wise. The system is scheduled to be operational by March of next year.

RIP: Mission Impossible for PC
GameSpot News confirmed with Infogrames North America that Mission Impossible for the PC has been cancelled worldwide. The title, originally planned for a fall 1999 release, got the ax after the publisher determined that "the quality of the game wasn't high enough" to release.

Micheal Mullen
Good Luck, Mike.
It's with great regret that we announce that our senior news editor, Micheal Mullen, has decided to leave our ranks for a position with Electronic Arts. Mike has been with GameSpot since its inception almost three years ago, and he will be sorely missed. Best of luck in all your endeavors, Mike.
Gamespot Staff
Infogrames COO Departs
GameSpot News has learned that Infogrames USA's COO, Stan Roach, has left the company for personal and professional reasons. Since the company had two COOs, Yves Legris will become the company's only COO.
